course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc., E-learning platforms
opinions: It isn't as effective as traditional learning and a lot of things I'm supposed to learn are better off done in practice . The benefits of this is that I don't have to get ready for school and I can always watch any missed lectures that I didn't attend. Challenges of course outweigh the benefits... Internet connection of involved parties is sometimes awful, so much time is spent preparing for the class, the huge number of students in the zoom doesn't permit adequate questioning of the particular topic and it just doesn't feel like learning to me!

course: Humanities - business, law, international studies, etc.
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc.
opinions: Tbh, trash trash. In class, you are able to place your full attention unlike from home. It does not also consider 3 part influences on my ability to attend the class. If there is no electricity, there is probably no internet and accessing that class will be a nightmare. In class, lecturer is able to give a question and ask you to solve it, then it becomes an easy way to query where you didn't understand from classmates or the lecturer. Discussions are also difficult with online schooling.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc.
opinions: It's definitely harder. Paying attention is more difficult, the assignments are heavier and quite time consuming, and staring at screens all day causes headaches. However, even with traditional methods of teaching it was still tiring but in a different way. The challenges were poor internet connection and power outages which would render some unable to attend classes. The benefits include learning from home so you're comfortable and you don't have to think about commuting. In terms of acquiring knowledge I feel like there's no difference. We still have to read a lot on our own.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc.
opinions: It's been really hectic especially studying chemistry online with little to no visual aids and no experiments. The work load is thrice the normal workload when we are in school physically. Lectures seem to really rash through topics and it's really anxiety fuelling to ask questions in a meeting if you didn't understand. My experience hasn't been great but the only thing i love about online learning is that  the flexibility of hours and that I can attend without thinking about my physical appearance

course: Humanities - business, law, international studies, etc.
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc., E-learning platforms
opinions:
To be honest, the school has done really well with teaching daily online classes. 
Some lecturers are just unable to use technology.
alt_opinions: Wouldn't mind staying online. It means I don't have to deal with school and it's poor resources everyday while I can just be at home.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc., E-learning platforms
opinions:
In comparison to traditional/Offline learning, I preferred offline learning as I was less distracted in classes. I face network struggles and constantly have to catch up on online classes as a result of struggles with online classes.
On the other hand, it has kept me on top of my assignments somehow as I tend to finish my work more on time. 
I wish that we were tested in better fashion considering this is online learning. The refusing to move forward with learning and retain traditional testing methods is a clear indicator as to why our education system is considered low as a whole, in Australia they understood that a pandemic was ongoing and instead of giving the students written tests for technical units like Engineering, they gave students tasks and graded them on those given tasks. 
Online learning has exposed our poor education system, even in "top tier" Universities such as Strathmore and their donkey-like stubbornness to adapt to the pandemic and make changes accordingly.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related

opinions:
It's really exhausting to have to look at a screen from 8-5
The teachers try to provide learning materials 
Communication barrier is the biggest issue because sometimes we have a week long blackout and the network isn't as good so you miss a week's worth of class 
Or the lec does not know how to use the platform so he or she is just unclear all through
Mathematics classes are the worst because you literally don't understand and the lec just moves on without you

It's a challenge as compared to face to face learning and I believe that as soon as it's safe to resume the latter schools should do so.
alt_opinions: It's been tough..most lecturers are trying to minimise their exposure time to students,others don't show up at all and we're forced to rely on online learning heavily.

Overall I feel you need very high self control to consistently keep up with classes and also be privileged enough to access to things like computers and the good internet.

course: Humanities - business, law, international studies, etc.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc.
opinions:
It's like when you're watching a video on YouTube, then get distracted by another tab. It lacks the human touch of a classroom, both in the lecturer/student and student/students (with classmates or schoolmates)relationships...group work, has to be done online too. 
Living in a noisy neighbourhood, is crazy, for home study and also while attending the classes.
It is flexible, alright, in the sense that you don't even have to actively participate(most of the time the audio and video broadcasting from the students' devices is disabled), and in the event that one misses a session, they can get a recorded version of it. Saves on time too, that would have otherwise been lost trying to manoeuvre through traffic, if one doesn't reside within the school.

opinions: It is poor on our end. Using google meet that only accommodates 100 students yet my class has 180 peopl- royal rumble every day. There's the problem of a online poor library even the lexis nexis subscription the school didn't renew. I honestly believe no professional body should endorse these degrees. Then the jokers at CLE decided no other online exam should be offered but the online classes should continue as they are. Smh! Is evaluation better than learning the course?
alt_opinions: We have not shifted although I wish we did.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc.
opinions: It has been not been as good as it is put out to be in public. Starting from the quality of connection on the lecturer's side to the complete inconsistency of hosting of classes as per the timetables. In terms of the extent to which we, as students, grasp information that is being taught, I would say we are able to retain close to nothing from it. Perhaps, it might be my school alone in the entire university, but the experience of online learning was horrible for me.

course: Humanities - business, law, international studies, etc.
tools: E-learning platforms
opinions:
I love it! I can be able to have my classes anywhere! 
For me, getting to my school was terrible. I live in Kileleshwa And my school is all the way in Juja. It would take me at most an hour to get there... and going back home was way worrsee. 
With online classes I’m saving a lot of time, so I can work and still have my classes. 

Although, I’d love to access the library in my school for research purposes. But the good thing is that almost every book in that library can be accessed online. 

Online classes are everything! 

Also, I’m not trying to catch COVID-19.

course: STEM - sciences, tech, engineering, math related
tools: Video Conferencing tools - Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, etc., E-learning platforms
opinions:
It has been an entirely new experience that actually took me by surprise. In comparison to the traditional methods of teaching, I can classify it as more relaxed mode which can have both negative and positive impacts in my academic life. Positive in that I have to be more conscious and manage myself during lessons to pick up the most from the lecturers. In a normal class setup the distractions are often limited though still present. 
I can also pick a positive from the online classes whereby it gives me a chance to do a little more research and gain a greater depth in understanding. 

My only challenge will be the flexibility I have where I can miss class and still appear present by records and probably miss a lot of important details i would have picked up in a normal class setup.
